awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Byte-Addressable I/O Everywhere
awd_abstract_narration:
The file system interface provided by today's operating systems has not kept up with available hardware. Consequently, the applications do not take full performance advantage of the current capabilities. This project will explore new software and hardware architectures to improve the storage interface with the potential to provide a uniform, secure and performant interface across a range of storage mechanisms.
?
To achieve these goals, the project will explore novel kernel- and user-space mechanisms to access storage systems ranging from local persistent memory to remote key-value stores. Further, research thrust will examine means of providing the flexibility of these two storage classes in bus-attached devices such as solid state drives, which are mostly limited to a fixed-size block storage interface. New mechanisms will be evaluated via software implementation in a research operating system and full-system simulation of proposed hardware features.
?
The rapid adoption of cloud models such as serverless computing has resulted in a wide range of applications which are free of the backwards-compatibility constraints, creating opportunities for novel research in this area to benefit cloud computing systems, which may result in technology transfer. Further, the project will involve and mentor students at the undergraduate, masters, and PhD levels, and in particular will seek to involve masters degree students from a departmental program that actively recruits from under-represented groups.

Software developed as part of this project will be made available under an open-source license. When possible, traces collected during this work will be submitted to the trace repository at http://iotta.snia.org. A project website (http://khoury.northeastern.edu/~pjd/nonblock) will be used to make available artifacts, code, and data resulting from this project, including containerized versions of key simulations for reproducibility. The website will be maintained beyond the duration of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For decades, persistent computer storage was closely identified with disk drives using a block interface, and single-machine file systems running on top. Yet the last 15 years have seen a surge of new storage technologies which we are still struggling to adapt to and best utilize. The advent of solid-state storage and SSDs has dramatically changed the landscape of the fundamental storage devices used in systems, while cloud-scale services have transformed how our applications use that storage in networked and cloud systems.

This work aims to address a range of challenges in integrating these new generations of storage devices, systems, and services. In cooperation with multiple industry partners (primarily NetApp, Red Hat, and IBM) we have investigated novel forms of magnetic recording, flash storage, and new methods of applying emerging distributed storage modalities. It seeks new interfaces and applications for these new technologies, to better integrate these new building blocks into high-performance and efficient storage stacks.

Technical merits of this project include:

1. Cross-layer optimization of caching for object storage and data analytics: connecting the scheduler in Spark (or similar analytic frameworks) to the caching layer in the storage subsystem allows the cache to "see the future", prefetching data so that it is in place when it is needed, and evicting it as soon as it is no longer needed. Results demonstrate large speedups with cache sizes too small for appreciable effect when managed with least-recently-used (LRU) or similar traditional caching algorithms.

2. Novel translation layers for shingled magnetic recording (SMR) disks: SMR increases drive capacity while greatly degrading performance for many workloads, due to its inability to modify data in place and the resulting need to perform garbage collection. uCache promotes frequently-rewritten data to a small high-performance section of the disk, greatly reducing this performance penalty.

3. Efficient, high-speed storage for cloud virtual machines: by using a translation layer approach to combining widely-used write-once storage technology (Simple Storage Service or S3) with local caching, this work allows much higher-performance and more efficient virtual disks, which serve as the underlying storage mechanism for cloud virtual machines.

Broader impacts include:

1. Funding and research opportunities to multiple graduate students, including a female computer science PhD student who graduated and is now at Google Research.

2. Contribution to open-source projects and industry development. Portions of the cross-layer optimization have been accepted into the widely-used Ceph storage system, and we are working with industry partners to incorporate the virtual machine storage system into this and other projects.

Modified by: Peter Desnoyers
